content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given the structure of this game, it seems like a form of the Prisoner's Dilemma where there is a dominant strategy that is not mutually beneficial when both players choose it. In this case, R seems to be the dominant strategy because choosing R when they choose B yields a higher payoff (0$ vs 42$), and vice versa. However, if both players choose R, they both receive 45$.

Since I don't know the strategy of my anonymous opponent, it would make sense for me to choose R as well. This is because even if there is a chance that they will choose B (in which case I get 0$), the potential gain when they do choose R outweighs the loss in this scenario (45$ instead of 12$).

However, since we are playing 75 rounds, it might be more beneficial to mix strategies to avoid being predictable and potentially exploit their strategy. For instance, I could start with a few rounds of R, then switch to B for some rounds, and then go back to R. But, without knowing the opponent's behavior, it is impossible to predict what would be optimal in this case.

In conclusion, I will choose R (R{}) for the first round, but after that, I might consider mixing strategies based on observed patterns from my opponent.

Since my opponent chose B in the previous round, I will switch to B for the next round (B{}) to try and take advantage of their choice in the previous round. This could potentially lead to a higher payoff in future rounds if they continue to choose B. However, it is still possible that they may switch strategies as well, so I should be prepared to adjust my own strategy accordingly based on observed patterns.

Since we are in a situation where both choosing B results in a lower payoff compared to when we both choose R, it might make sense to switch strategies and choose R for the next round (R{}) to try and increase our potential earnings.
